title: 111_hr1648
content: The "Fiscal Integrity Through Transparency and Technology (FITT) Act of 2009" is aimed at constraining the growth of the federal government by amending Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. The "Fiscal Integrity Through Transparency and Technology (FITT) Act of 2009" amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to restrict budget growth based on allowable growth percentage tied to economic indicators like GDP and worker earnings. The "Fiscal Integrity Through Transparency and Technology (FITT) Act of 2009" amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to restrict budget growth based on economic indicators. Waiver of subsection (a) requires a two-thirds vote in the House of Representatives or Senate. Title II of the FITT Act focuses on efficiency and responsibility in the federal government. Section 201 requires federal departments and agencies to submit annual reports to the Government Accountability Office. Each Federal department and agency must submit an annual report to the Comptroller General on total operating costs, including details on waste, fraud, and abuse. The Comptroller General will randomly audit 10 percent of these reports. Intelligence departments and agencies must also report their total operating costs and details on waste, fraud, and abuse to the Select Committee on Intelligence of the House of Representatives. The first reports on waste, fraud, and abuse must be submitted within one year of the enactment of the Act. The Comptroller General must submit an annual report to Congress on the results of reports from federal departments and agencies. The first report is due within 18 months of the Act's enactment. Additionally, there is a plan for reducing operational costs of federal departments and agencies. Each Federal department or agency must create a plan to reduce operational costs by 41.67 percent within one year of the Act's enactment. Implementation of the plan must occur within 10 years. Annual progress reports on the plan's implementation must be submitted to Congress. SEC. 204. INFORMING TAXPAYERS. The Secretary of the Treasury will include a statement on tax returns showing the total amount of waste, fraud, and abuse by all Federal departments and agencies for the most recent year. The Comptroller General will report annually to the Secretary of the Treasury the total amount of waste, fraud, and abuse based on reports submitted by Federal departments and agencies.
